definition: the Five Hegemons of the Spring and Autumn period (770-476 BC), namely: Duke Huan of Qi 齊桓公|齐桓公[Qi2 Huan2 gong1], Duke Wen of Jin 晉文公|晋文公[Jin4 Wen2 gong1], King Zhuang of Chu 楚莊王|楚庄王[Chu3 Zhuang1 wang2], and alternatively Duke Xiang of Song 宋襄公[Song4 Xiang1 gong1] and Duke Mu of Qin 秦穆公[Qin2 Mu4 gong1] or King Helu of Wu 吳王闔閭|吴王阖闾[Wu2 wang2 He2 Lu:2] and King Gou Jian of Yue 越王勾踐|越王勾践[Yue4 wang2 Gou1 Jian4]

autumn/fall/harvest time

five/5
hegemon/tyrant/lord/feudal chief/to rule by force/to usurp/(in modern advertising) master
Seven Powerful States of the Warring States, namely: 齊|齐[Qi2], 楚[Chu3], 燕[Yan1], 韓|韩[Han2], 趙|赵[Zhao4], 魏[Wei4] and 秦[Qin2]
Duke Huan of Qi (reigned 685-643 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸

King Zhuang of Chu (reigned 613-591 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
Qi state of Western Zhou and the Warring states (1122-265 BC), centered in Shandong
vassal state
the state of Chu, one of the most important of the small states contending for power in China between 770 and 223 BC, located around present-day Hubei
the state of Qin, one of the seven states of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Guan Zhong (-645 BC), famous politician of Qi 齊國|齐国 of Spring and Autumn period/known as Guangzi 管子
a restricted view through a bamboo tube
the Zhou dynasty from 1027 BC
Duke Xiang of Song (reigned 650-637 BC), sometimes considered one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
the Spring and Autumn (770-476 BC) and Warring States (475-221 BC) periods
Lu, vassal state at the time of the Zhou Dynasty 周朝|周朝[Zhou1 chao2], located in the southwest of present-day Shandong 山東|山东[Shan1 dong1], birthplace of Confucius
King Wu of Zhou (-1043), personal name Ji Fa 姬發|姬发, reigned 1046-1043 BC as first king of Western Zhou dynasty 1046-1043 BC
Zhou Dynasty/Western Zhou 西周 (1046-771 BC) and Eastern Zhou 東周|东周 (770-221 BC)
